TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Health. I remind the minister of his Prime Minister's election statement that:

QUESTION.PARA: Medicare is working. The funding in Medicare is working.

How is it that one year out from this reassuring comment by Mr Keating the minister is seeking an increase in the Medicare levy? Will the minister categorically rule out an increase in the Medicare levy in the term of this parliament?

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not within my power to rule in or out any increase in the Medicare levy. I am but a humble health minister so I could not possibly rule it in or out. But that having been said, I take the view that it is not appropriate for me to either confirm or deny any speculation on the budget, and I will not be doing so.

PARA.TAB: But in response to Senator Newman's question, `Is Medicare working?', overwhelmingly and resoundingly I would say, `yes'. Five times in a row Australians have said it was working, and they were right each time. The numbers of them who believe it to be true grow every year.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the waiting lists?

—Let us get to the waiting lists. That is a very good question. If we believe that 112,000 were on the waiting lists—as the AIHW said the other day—that means that 97 per cent of those who walk in the door of a public hospital in Australia get treated quickly and get treated well; 97 per cent get treated straight away.

PARA.TAB: Then, if we look at that figure, we see that only a third of those wait longer than six months; a third of them wait only a couple of weeks. A third of them wait six months or more. The fact therefore is that we are down to one per cent. I would have thought that any system that could deliver for 99 per cent of those who go through its doors is doing phenomenally well. However, I take the view that if there is even one per cent who ought to be treated better we have an obligation to improve the system further and get to them as well.

So, yes, I will be making suggestions to do more in public health so that it is not 99 per cent who get treated well under Medicare but it is 100 per cent. No nation in the world could make the boast about the 99 per cent that we can—not one. This is the best health system going, but this government, which created it, will now make it better.

That stands in stark contrast to the opposition's health policy; we still do not know what it is. Senator Woods, who was the former opposition health spokesman when a member of the House of Representatives, has just been appointed to the Senate. His health policy was ditched last year. The opposition still does not have one. I notice, however, that Senator Bishop is trying to help the opposition out, but we might have more to say about that later today. I am only warming up on this; there is a long way to go.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Trade. A recent report has indicated that levels of Australian investment in South-East Asia have been relatively low. Does this mean that Australian companies have not taken full advantage of trade opportunities which exist in the region?

—There have been such reports recently, not least because I recently had the opportunity publicly to release a study by the East Asia analytical unit of my department, entitled `Changing tack: Australian investment in South-East Asia'. The report showed, as Senator Childs correctly stated, that, while Australian trade with South-East Asian countries has been growing very strongly over the past decade—it has made a very significant contribution to Australian economic growth—the reverse has happened to investment. Australian investors' relative interest in ASEAN countries has fallen throughout the 1980s. There has been a focus instead on Europe and the United States.

PARA.TAB: There are some very understandable reasons for that, particularly in relation to the 1992 situation in Europe. It is, nevertheless, contrary to one's expectation and an indication that opportunities in the region are being lost. Obviously it is not for the government to decide where to invest. Those are decisions for companies and enterprises, based on their judgments of the commercial factors of any decisions they are making. But the report does highlight that there are opportunities in South-East Asia which may be appropriately considered by Australian business. The reason for initiating the report and for now promoting it is that we want business to consider taking up those opportunities.

One of the most important things is that the report, hopefully and I think finally, puts to rest the view that in some way investment overseas—in this instance, investment in South-East Asia—costs jobs in Australia. In fact, it makes it quite clear that most Australian investors in South-East Asia source at least some of the inputs for their offshore operations from Australia. So, rather than diverting productive activity from Australia, much of this investment is driving exports, boosting production and creating more jobs in Australia.

This is not in any way a blanket endorsement that every Australian firm should invest in the region. Each one has to make its own judgment on its own circumstances and on the opportunities in front of it. But the clear message is that investment in South-East Asia will be a very important part of Australia's trade and economic strategy collectively and for many of the companies which go to make up the Australian economy.

There are a number of recommendations in the report and it is particularly important that they be considered at the Commonwealth-state trade and investment forum scheduled for July. The recommendations are designed to improve information, to assist in the development of networks and to build on Australia's advantages in the region. So I think it is a very important report. It does not provide all the answers, but it raises some issues which are fundamental and central to the development of Australia's trade and economic strategy, particularly in relation to South-East Asia.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I refer to the further encouragement offered last week by the latest figures on employment. Is the minister able to provide any information to the Senate on the latest available data on employment growth? Further, what are the prospects for employment of women resulting from the latest data on employment growth?

—It is very pleasing to be able to report that the February employment figures released last week are very good news for the economy but, of course, not very good news for the opposition. The labour force figures released confirm that economic recovery is generating sustained employment growth. During February, the number of full-time jobs rose by 39,800 and total employment increased by 14,400. Employment is now 217,500 higher than a year ago. Unemployment is down by 34,600 over the past year. Employment growth is flowing to both full-time and part-time jobs. It is pleasing that, over the last six months, a clear growth trend has emerged for full-time jobs. In the last six months, full-time employment has grown by 96,900 and part-time employment has grown by 54,500. These are all excellent signs of growth in the economy.

PARA.TAB: A further very significant feature of the latest data is that employment for women is at its highest level ever. Job opportunities for women are very good indeed. For the year to February 1994, female employment grew by 104,000, which represents a growth of 3.2 per cent. Female employment is 46,500, or 1.4 per cent, higher than at the peak of the business cycle in July 1990. Female full-time employment has grown by 50,800, or 2.7 per cent, during the past year. Male employment, by contrast, has grown by 3.6 per cent, or 113,000.

The main factors which explain the improvement in employment for women include an increase in the participation rate and changes in industry structure. The labour force female participation rate has increased by 15 per cent over the decade to 1993-94; that is, it has increased from 44.9 per cent to 51.7 per cent. Industries that have shown this growth, that predominantly employ women and that have grown the fastest are, namely, the community services, recreation, finance, property and business services and retail trade industries.

The most significant step forward in female employment last weekend was the fact that Carmen Lawrence will now become the federal member for Fremantle. She will do an excellent job. It was a great pleasure to be involved in that campaign. I was able to see how the people of Fremantle put down the smear campaign that some members opposite ran against Carmen Lawrence—particularly Senator Campbell, who accused her of murdering somebody in Western Australia in the recent past. It was an outrageous smear campaign, which is typical of the opposition's negative policies and negative comments. It ignored the very good news on the economic front, particularly on employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Transport to the proposed sale of the Australian National Line. Firstly, is it true that the government has watered down its own conditions for the proposed sale of the Australian National Line? Why is that? Secondly, is it true that ANL ships will now be able to be registered in countries with substandard labour and safety conditions? Thirdly, how does the minister explain the apparent hypocrisy when, at the same time, his government is making such a big noise about the ships of shame which threaten our barrier reef and its actions could end up making ANL ships, ships of shame themselves?

—I advise Senator Kernot to leap upon more contemporary leaks. She is a little out of date with that one. If the Australian Financial Review wishes to publish in March leaks of views which it thinks might have been made last June, it at least needs to get a little more up to date about things that have been said publicly by the Minister for Transport this month.

PARA.TAB: On 4 March this year the Minister for Transport and the Minister for Finance jointly announced a due diligence process for ANL. I am not going to confirm what cabinet decisions may or may not have been made last year, but if there had been one, as reported, that was made in June of 1993, it has been quite clearly superseded by the decision of February this year and announced in March by the minister.

Through the course of the due diligence process which has been announced, the government will be conducting extensive consultations with the unions, the ACTU and the industry. Once the findings of the due diligence are known, any decision about the ownership structure will once again be undertaken only after consultation with those same parties.

Obviously the party has a policy on the ANL sale. We will not in any way be pre-empting the processes of party policy in the lead-up to this year's national conference. There will be a lot of consultation before we get to any decisions of the sort the honourable senator might make.

If there was any accuracy in the report of the Financial Review about what might have been decided in June—to the extent that it was ever accurate—it has been superseded. It is the government's preference that ANL should continue to play its part in Australian shipping and that it should continue to operate as Australian owned, Australian crewed and Australian flagged with its employees working under Australian award conditions. The outcome of the process will be the product of consultation after the due diligence process and after consideration, as is always the case, of the policy of the party as determined at our national conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security advise the Senate of the government's policies to increase self-provision among sole parents? In particular, can the minister advise the Senate on the progress of the jobs, education and training program?

—I am very pleased to answer this question and, in particular, to take another opportunity to debunk some of the continuing myths about sole parents, one of which is that sole parents somehow arrive as teenage mothers. The facts are the opposite. The majority of parents become sole parents as a result of divorce or breakdown of de facto relationships.

PARA.TAB: The average age of a sole parent—this might entertain the Senate—is about 33 for women and 38 for men. The average number of children of a sole parent pensioner is about 1.8, near enough to two children. The average duration on the sole parent pension is about 3.4 years for women. Many sole parents use the sole parent pension merely as crisis management and a large number give up the pension within three months—that is, they are on the pension for only three months. Very importantly, teenage sole parents make up only three per cent of sole parent pensioners. That figure is actually down from nine per cent in 1980. That is in line with the trend of declining numbers of teenagers giving birth.

The government has been very concerned to see that all social security recipients are assisted. It has three main aims—adequacy of payments, targeting those most in need, and encouraging people on the pension to move off the pension and to become self-sufficient as soon as possible. The JET program has done that with very great success.

The JET program, as people would know, covers three portfolios: the Department of Social Security, the Department of Employment, Education and Training and the child-care section of the Department of Human Services and Health. It assists sole parent pensioners and their families by providing information and counselling, directing those people to the appropriate training, study or even employment, and arranging child care.

The program quite clearly has put paid to any notion that sole parents are unmotivated or do not want to get off the pension. In fact, the evidence shows quite the opposite. In the six months from July to December last year, some 7,600 JET clients gained jobs, an increase of around 50 per cent over the same period in 1992-93 and nearly 180 per cent higher than in the same period in 1991-92. It is clear that sole parents participating in JET are getting a good share of the expanding job market to which my colleague Senator Schacht just referred. In addition, nearly 4,200 sole parent pensioners have taken up education and over 12,000 have taken up opportunities to train through a labour market program.

The JET program is making a difference in education, training and employment. In fact, the government should feel very pleased with these results because they show, as those figures indicate, that sole parents are motivated and are very happy to take up those opportunities and that government assistance is helping them.

The best kind of flattery is imitation. New Zealand has just announced that it will trial a new program called Compass, which is based on the Australian JET model. I believe that is something from which we should take great heart. So well do we do it here that we have become a model for at least New Zealand.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy and I refer to the minister's recent visit to rural Queensland, where he was reported as praising the Queensland grain growers drought recovery package. Will the minister confirm that the exceptional circumstances RAS funding is to continue after 30 June? When does the minister expect to finalise discussions with the Queensland government on the Queensland farmers' proposal to set up a rural adjustment unit?

The terms of reference for that review have only just been completed. When the actual review commences, officers of my department will liaise directly with the peak bodies concerned. During the conduct of the review there will be wide consultation on it.

PARA.TAB: I am very pleased to say in passing, as Senator Boswell knows, that I visited Queensland a few days ago and, in cooperation with the farmers' groups, had proposed to visit the worst drought affected areas that had not received any substantial rain for up to four years. The itinerary had been suggested to me by those grower groups. As Senator Boswell would be aware, the trips to those areas had to be called off after I arrived in Queensland because the areas had been flooded and were under six inches of water.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you do that?

—No. I am not taking credit for that; I do not want to be blamed for the floods. I am pleased though, of course, for the growers concerned that have had, in a lot of cases, seven or eight successive crop losses on the trot. I am quite sure they would have been much happier swimming around in the rain than sitting down talking to me about the drought. But, for the advice of Senator Boswell, that matter is under consideration at the moment.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the proposals that were put to me by the Queensland grain growers association to effectively have the state delivered element of RAS delivered as part of a single body and to have a more cohesive method of delivering it, as I said publicly at the time, that proposal in my view does have merit. This morning I finalised the letters that I will be sending, probably later today, to the relevant ministers in the Queensland government to get their reaction to it.

Currently, the Commonwealth funds RAS very extensively. I think the current budget is in the order of $176 million of Commonwealth funding to RAS. If there is a better way of delivering that assistance to farmers we are certainly prepared to consider it; but the agencies that actually deliver it on the ground are agencies of the state government. Again I stress—because I made it very clear while I was in Queensland—that it will effectively be a decision of the Queensland state government as to whether the proposal has merit or not. But I will be communicating that to the Queensland government this week and I will be quite keenly awaiting its response.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women. There is no intention to move away from the 20-year phase-in period for moving women to a pensionable age of 65. But we are very concerned to take close account of the changing labour market force participation and women's increased access to superannuation, which are both reasons why the government is intent on introducing this change in the first place and sticking to it.

PARA.TAB: Access to superannuation has improved dramatically for women. It has risen from 40 per cent in 1988 to about 88 per cent in 1992 for women employed full-time, and it has risen from nine per cent to 55 per cent for women employed part-time. The 40- to 50-year age group has shown the most significant increase of women into the work force. Between 1982 and 1993, the participation rates have gone from 47 per cent to 65 per cent for married women aged 45 to 54, and from 60 per cent to 69 per cent for single women in the same age group.

TAB.TAB: Senator Calvert asked the Minister for Administrative Services, without notice, on 3 March 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is the Minister aware that the Department of Administrative Services has entered the private sector training market by advertising for public enrolment in its Staff Development and Information Technology courses?
(2) Can the Minister advise whether this practice of actively competing against the Private Sector training facilitators is to occur Australia-wide?

(3) Has the Minister received any complaints about this new foray and does the Minister consider it appropriate for a tax-payer funded organisation to compete against private operators who provide jobs for thousands of Australians?

(4) Does the Minister accept that this will adversely affect existing training providers and is the Government prepared to accept responsibility for any job losses which will inevitably occur unless this practice is stopped?

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable Senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) I presume that the advertisement to which Senator Calvert refers is contained in the feature article on `Training for a Better Future' in the Hobart Mercury on 20 January 1994.

DAS Staff Development in Tasmania was invited to contribute to this feature as one of the significant public sector training providers in the State. The feature was designed to explain the career paths available to young people, the opportunities available for re-training and the advantages of continuous training programs. It was entirely appropriate for DAS Staff Development to contribute to the feature as public sector career development and training are the rationale for the organisation's existence.

The advertisement was not designed to seek work in the private sector market, nor was it a `new foray' into that market. It served to advertise the availability to the public sector market in Tasmania of courses run by DAS Staff Development, which, as part of DAS Support Services is operating on a market-priced, competitive basis in the public sector marketplace.
In Tasmania in the financial year to date, three private sector employees have been trained, all as top-up participants in scheduled courses conducted by DAS Staff Development.

(2) DAS Staff Development is in direct competition with private sector providers for work in the public sector Australia wide and indeed, within DAS itself. However, DAS Staff Development is a major user of private sector consultants' services. In the financial year to date, over $650 000 has been expended on consultants' services and by the end of the financial year, this figure will be close to $1m. DAS Staff Development both competes against the private sector providers for work in the public sector and also employs them extensively for assignments which demand skills and expertise which are not present in the organisation.

While it is not DAS Staff Development's intention to sell services to the private sector, it is necessary in a competitive market-place to advertise in a modest way to attract a larger share of the public sector market.
(3) I have not received any complaints about this issue although I am aware that one of my colleagues has dealt with one complaint about the matter in Tasmania.

As I have stated above, DAS Staff Development does operate in a competitive environment where private sector trainers seek and obtain large amounts of work in the public sector domain. This Government recognises that such competition is healthy for both the public sector providers and recipients of these services. However, it means that public sector providers such as DAS Staff Development have to operate in a competitive way to maintain their market share and this will continue to be the case in the public sector.
(4) I do not accept that the current marketing practices of DAS Staff Development will adversely affect private sector training providers.

As I stated in my preliminary comments on this matter, the principle which applies for all DAS businesses in competing with private sector providers for private sector work is the principle of competitive neutrality. This entails the application of all statutory charges, and equivalent taxes to DAS businesses in order to put them on an even footing with their private sector competitors and it is a principle endorsed in the Hilmer Report. The commercialisation of DAS has given the private sector access to potential income in excess of $800m annually, which was not available before commercialisation and for which DAS businesses now compete in open competition.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

PARA.TAB: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Senator Collins), to a question without notice asked by Senator Tambling this day, relating to informal voting in an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission election.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps I should indicate that it was a non-answer, as the minister has had to take the question on notice and seek the information that is required. I remind the Senate and Senator Collins that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission elections were held on Saturday, 4 December 1993. We are now addressing this issue some 3 1/2 months later. The election to which I referred, the ward of Nhulunbuy South, was declared on 14 January 1994. I would have anticipated that ATSIC would have precipitated some action in this regard. This issue was raised with me at Nhulunbuy on 25 January this year. I discussed it with officers of ATSIC at Nhulunbuy and was informed at that time that it was likely that a new election would be called. Therefore, I was appalled today when Senator Collins was not able to acknowledge any information on this issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not my portfolio area.

—The question I put to Senator Collins today was very much his portfolio. It related to what ATSIC initiatives were now being taken on this issue. Last week the Australian Electoral Commission issued an electoral news file, No. 39, dated February 1994. That news file summarised the various ATSIC elections all around Australia. In it were the Northern Territory results, which included the three wards of Nhulunbuy—Nhulunbuy East, Nhulunbuy South and Nhulunbuy West.

PARA.TAB: In respect of the ward that I raised during question time today—Nhulunbuy South—four people were named as the successful candidates: Timothy Lalara, Nancy (Burgoyne) Lalara, Samuel Numamurdirdi and Lindsay Joshua. Let me indicate that I take no particular offence at any of those people being named. But what I do take offence at is the way in which this matter has been allowed to drag on, given that it was well known to the Electoral Commission and ATSIC well before the declaration of the poll.

I have been able to ascertain that the problems arose because the ballot papers were not put in the required declaration envelopes but inserted straight into the ballot box. Despite the fact that the Electoral Commission team that visited Nhulunbuy had been trained, for some time it chose not to carry out this important procedure. At some date before 14 January it was known to the Electoral Commission that this procedure was to be adopted. In fact, it was incorrectly not adopted.

The fact that at the end of the day the successful candidates were determined by pulling names out of a hat—and that is not alluded to in any way in the AEC Electoral Newsfile—is a very important omission of an important fundamental electoral principle. It is staggering that this matter has been allowed to drag on. As I said earlier, this matter was known to ATSIC. It was certainly conveyed to me on 25 January by staff at Nhulunbuy. I am, therefore, alarmed that the minister was not able to react today during question time. I would have thought Mr Tickner would have provided Senator Collins with an appropriate brief and response on this issue. It is not good enough for the government to now camouflage very important points of principle with regard to an election—the fact that there are over 800 people eligible to vote in this particular ward.

I note from the detailed news file that the turnout in that electorate was 57.87 per cent and that the actual number of voters was 489. However, 477 votes were rejected. That meant that 10 formal votes and two informal votes were recorded. There was, therefore, a quota of three for the election. But, of course, the quota was not used—the names were picked out of a hat.

I remind the Senate that the form shows that, whilst there were four vacancies in this ward, there were 10 nominations. This makes a mockery of Australia's election procedures. I would have thought a Labor government, with its high principles in this area, would have determined this matter well in advance of this time.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Primary Industries and Energy)

TALK.START.PARA: —No-one is trying to camouflage anything. TALK.START.PARA: —It is in here.

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that the President has received the following letter, dated 14 March 1994, from Senator Newman:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President
Pursuant to Standing Order 75, I give notice that today I propose to move:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The intention of the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, to increase the Medicare levy, thereby breaking yet another of the Government's election promises, and causing even greater damage to private health insurance and the health care of all Australians.

Is the proposal supported?

TAB.EMPHASIS: More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places—

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The intention of the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, to increase the Medicare levy, thereby breaking yet another of the Government's election promises, and causing even greater damage to private health insurance and the health care of all Australians.

Mr Deputy President, all honourable senators have to remember that the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, owes his leadership to a commitment to the ALP Left and to some members of the Centre Left not to increase the health tax take for Australians in the form of a co-payment. I am interested to see that the minister in the chamber, who is presumably going to defend the real health minister, is Senator Crowley. She would be proud, I think, to take credit for having swung the numbers behind the Prime Minister in delivering the Prime Ministership to him. The numbers apparently seem to depend upon the co-payment which has been introduced being overturned.

PARA.TAB: I draw the attention of honourable senators to a report in the Sunday Telegraph of 15 December 1991 in which Senator Crowley is reported as saying that she had contacted Mr Keating and asked whether this meant that, if in the future he became leader of the party, the decision would be reversed. The article states:
"Mr Keating confirmed that this would be the case, that a Government led by him would reverse the decision as a matter of priority."

SPEECH.PARA: The article quotes Senator Crowley as saying:

PARA.TAB: "I want it changed as soon as possible and Mr Keating has said he will do it—

SPEECH.PARA: The report goes on:

PARA.TAB: Although sources close to Mr Keating confirmed he made the pledge to abolish the co-payment "from Day One" the former treasurer is maintaining his tactic of public silence and refused to comment.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that the facts of that statement were borne out because as soon as Mr Keating became Prime Minister, he abolished the co-payments. So it is true to say that the price of the leadership, getting the votes to overturn Bob Hawke, was that the co-payment decision be overturned. Now Mr Keating is refusing to rule out an increase in the health tax through the Medicare levy. They are all taxes by one name or the other. Yet on 13 January 1992, in an article quoting the former health minister, Mr Howe, the Canberra Times reported:

PARA.TAB: Mr Howe said the Government did not "really need to contemplate another rise" in the levy.

"What the Commonwealth is doing is saying for the next five years we will guarantee a significant increase in terms of funding . . . so I think that means there probably wouldn't be a need for a rise in the Medicare levy because effectively we would have covered the major area.

SPEECH.PARA: It was clearly spelt out prior to the election that Medicare is working. On 5 March, the Prime of Australia Mr Keating, said:
The funding in Medicare is working.

Nothing could be clearer than that. There was no suggestion then that Medicare was not working, so they needed more money to honour the promises of the new health minister and the need, which was already self-evident at the time of the election, to deal with Medicare and improve it. No, at that time it was concealed from the voters, just as it has been concealed from those who will vote in by-elections in the weeks ahead and those who voted in a by-election last Saturday. They were not told that there was going to be an increase in the Medicare levy. Once again, this Prime Minister was dancing around like a cat on a hot tin roof concealing the truth from the people who would pass judgement on him. I remind the Senate that Mr Hawke, when asked questions about increasing the Medicare levy in August 1991, said:
It would hit the low-income people more than would our (co-payments) arrangements.

This is the mob that got rid of the co-payments arrangements as part of the price for giving the Prime Minister the Prime Ministership. What are they going to do now? They are going to hit the low income people even more than they would have been hit with the previous arrangement for co-payments. That was confirmed by the previous Prime Minister, Mr Hawke.

PARA.TAB: These proposed reforms will increase the cost of private health insurance premiums by increasing the costs both to the funds and the hospitals. By that I am talking about the proposals that Senator Richardson put on the table a couple of months ago. He said that the changes will improve our health system by helping private health insurance. But they will not. They will simply add to the exodus from private health insurance. Last year 300,000 people got out of private health insurance, 80,000 in the last three months of the year. The proposals that Senator Richardson has put up will make that exodus a rush.

Only today a man rang my office and told me that he lives in Baulkham Hills, has three children and is just a battler. He has been onto the Prime Minister's office and he has been onto Senator Richardson's office, telling them that if this increase in the Medicare levy goes ahead he will be forced, despite his wishes, to get out of private health insurance because it will be the last straw that breaks the camel's back—he will have to rely totally on the public health system. It is essentially simply another tax. People like the battler from Baulkham Hills, the elderly, the self-funded retirees who are in such desperate difficulty at present as a result of this government's policies, against their wishes, will end up finding that they cannot afford to pay any kind of an increased levy and private health insurance.

The levy is symptomatic of the government's cowardice and total failure to realistically attack the problems of private health insurance and that is because it has no other solutions. The logical step would be to boost the numbers going into private health insurance by using financial support measures, but the opposition within the ALP to making private health insurance more attractive will not allow Senator Richardson to even consider such an option. The Medicare levy hike is even more desperate. Those who are hanging onto private insurance will decide that they can no longer afford insurance, a higher Medicare levy, their contribution through their general taxes and the gap payments. They will have to say enough is enough.

We had the Prime Minister and Senator Richardson going around the country last week spouting contradictory messages about this possible increase. It is certain, as day follows night, that it will be increased in the May budget in some form or other. The last time Senator Richardson increased the levy, which was only July last year—he increased it to 1.4 per cent—he said that it would reduce waiting times at hospitals. That has not happened. There are now about 112,000 people waiting for elective surgery, with more than 30 per cent of these people waiting on those lists for six months. Yet over and over again we have heard the minister dismiss these people waiting in pain as being `only three per cent'. Let me tell the government this: three per cent in pain is three per cent too many.

The levy rose from one per cent in February 1984 to 1.2 per cent in December 1986 to 1.4 per cent in July last year. The last time the minister said that he had no plans to increase the levy. On the Sunday program in May last year he said:

SPEECH.PARA: It's fairly high. People are paying 1.4 per cent of their income and that's a pretty hefty slug. I think there are other ways to contain the costs and pay for them than simply jacking up the levy.
Why has he changed his tune? It is because he cannot get the support from the Prime Minister for the measures that need taking, that we all understand need taking.

PARA.TAB: The minister to me is very much like a rat in a trap—he is going round and round trying to find solutions to the insoluble. His government will not wear a co-payment. He has been increasingly rationing health care. We have had the queues, I have mentioned, for so-called elective surgery. We have had delays in getting MRI scans; delays in getting the reports on the MRIs; delays in X-rays; delays in CAT scans; and refusal to allow certain important drugs onto the pharmaceutical benefits scheme in an attempt to contain costs. We have seen the attempt to cut out the opticians' tests and the refusal to allow the testing for osteoporosis for women as a diagnostic tool. These are all rationing measures, although the government will not admit them as such.

So the only other way for this rat in the trap is to break the election promises, do a U-turn on his own May 1993 statement and jack up the Medicare tax. He has spent his year promising more money for Aboriginal health, medical research, mental health and breast cancer—all extremely important issues—but now his day of reckoning is upon him. Where is the money coming from? There is no other solution to get more money into Australia's health system than to take some of the burden off the public sector. By giving financial support to low to middle income earners, only then can these queues be reduced, the rationing of services be reduced and some of the minister's promises at least be honoured.

The minister is to be pitied, although I guess he would reject the pity. He reminds me of a rat in a trap. He has had to admit that he has lost the support of his Prime Minister. He has been rejected by the Prime Minister publicly on two occasions in recent months for his so-called reform. The so-called power broker of the Labor Party is moving aside for a new entrant to his portfolio. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Health and Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories)

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President—

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It was terrific. I am quite speechless really, but I suppose that I had better say something. Senator Newman said that I have been put down by the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) so many times in the last few months. I thought it was the case that the reform proposals which she and others said would not go through cabinet did, and did so with its support.
—They haven't been through cabinet. Come on!
—They have and they got cabinet support.

PARA.TAB: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course we did. We put to that committee the proposals of cabinet that were endorsed.
—Rubbish.
—We did. That is a fact.
—They will come back again.

—I hope that they come back again; they need to. Senator Newman then said that I had disagreed with him a couple of times in the last week. Judging from question time, I know that Senator Newman is pretty expert in what has happened over the last week. She knows a lot about Fremantle and what occurred. But just in case she has forgotten a couple of things about Fremantle I will remind her of them.

PARA.TAB: I do not think whatever the Prime Minister and I did in the course of the last week did a lot of harm because the swing to the government in the by-election was absolutely unprecedented and says volumes about the opposition and the paucity of its policies. I was asked by some journalists on Friday morning about what the Prime Minister had to say and what I had to say and whether there was a conflict. I said exactly, `I agree with whatever the Prime Minister said'. I support my leader absolutely. I wonder whether any of those opposite would be prepared to say that about their leader.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support my leader.

—I believe that Senator Herron does. He is one who has signed up. But I have heard, not just on the grapevine but also through every newspaper, radio station and television station in the nation, that most of his colleagues do not. There is a great discussion about who their leader ought to be. If only they could agree on it.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I draw your attention to standing order 194, which concerns relevance. Senator Newman has raised a very important issue today with regard to Medicare. All we are hearing is Senator Richardson's views in respect of what he perceives to be a leadership problem, which has nothing whatsoever to do with the urgency motion raised by Senator Newman.

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! It would be helpful if the honourable minister did return to the motion in front of us.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall. I occasionally digress; it is very hard not to when it comes to the issue of Liberal leadership. It is such a fascinating subject. I note from Senator Newman's utterances that we are getting to the stage where a Liberal Party policy on health might be produced. There is no document that we can point to. All Senator Newman's spokesperson could say is that Mrs Bishop's contribution has been `a collection of our press releases'. We get opposition health policy only through press releases. Every now and again Senator Newman will trot one out. If we look at a press release, we have to discern whether it is a policy.

PARA.TAB: The spokesperson for Senator Newman said that what Mrs Bishop had said over the weekend was opposition health policy. That is very disappointing, because this is again in disagreement with Dr Hewson. I have to believe Dr Hewson—he is the leader—not Mrs Bishop, yet, and not Senator Newman, ever.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yet.

—Hello, there is another starter. Senator Newman says, `Yet'. There is another leadership candidate. That is about the 18th. It is an unbelievably big field. What a talent of riches from which to choose. On 6 February, Dr Hewson said:

SPEECH.PARA: Well, again, we will not be taking the same health policy to the next election. Bulk-billing was a policy. The abolition of bulk-billing was designed to deal with the problem of over-servicing. We will not be proposing that at the next election. We will be maintaining bulk-billing.
That is not what Mrs Bishop said. She said that it was only for the poor. Dr Hewson also said:
I think it was fair to say, at the last election, our health policy was pretty much an economic policy, if you like a health funding policy. I want a health care policy.

Want it he may; but get it he may not. Senator Newman and a whole host of others, now joined by Senator Woods, are not going to cop that health care aspect of it for a moment—not on your nelly; no fear. They do not want anything to do with health care; they want to go back to this hardline economics. But even Senator Newman was, I thought, at one point earlier this year getting close to adopting bulk-billing. She did try. She said:
Bulk-billing is not necessarily such a problem if it is truly an effective law that has been introduced. That was one of the big concerns we had, that bulk-billing led to over-servicing.
On 7 January, her spokesperson, who works overtime—this spokesperson gives it a hell of a go—said:
The message she is getting is that the policy certainly needs to be reviewed.

Amen to that. We all have to say absolutely that the policy needs to be reviewed. I am glad Senator Newman is getting that message; I am delighted. Senator Herron has not got that message; he thinks it is perfect as it is. But Senator Newman is getting the message, and that is good. The spokesperson continued:
But the decision to drop the policy is firmly a matter for the party room.

If it is firmly a matter for the party room, I suggest that Senator Newman takes it there because all of us would like to know what the policy will be. Will bulk-billing be retained for the poor only or will bulk-billing stay as it is now? We cannot tell from the quotes that I have just read out what the policy will be. I do not think Australians would mind knowing.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Obviously there is a need for a personal explanation.
—Senator Newman should not do it while I am speaking.
—I am happy to make it clear that the leader has spoken for the entire party; it has been through the party processes.
—What is it?

PARA.TAB: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston)—Order! That is not a point of order.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is even better; do not knock it, Senator West. We are told that what Dr Hewson said was true; that was all part of the policy. So when it was changed by Mrs Bishop, who said that she sees it as the safety net for those in need, what happened? Who was right? Was Mrs Bishop right or was Dr Hewson right? He did not make the same distinction.
—Mrs Bishop is not the leader of the party.

—So Mrs Bishop was wrong; now we have it. The difficulty is that this morning Senator Newman's spokesperson—the one who works all the overtime—said Mrs Bishop was basically right `in line with opposition policy'—in line, but against it, apparently. I do not know who to believe. I find this very perplexing. Here we are trying to discern what the opposition's policy is. Senator Newman says that Dr Hewson is right; she says that Mrs Bishop is right; and then she says that Mrs Bishop is wrong and that Dr Hewson is right. I do not know where to go from there.

PARA.TAB: I suspect the truth is, as usual, that the opposition still does not have a health policy and it is not going to get one. Therefore, when people such as Senator Newman get up to have a go at what the government has done on the question of health policy, the difficulty she faces is that she has no basis on which to comment—the opposition has no policy. Dr Woods' policy got thrown out; only Senator Herron still believes in it. Senator Newman does not, but she is not even sure how much of it she does not believe. The only thing about opposition members is that they are never sure what to believe in; they are never sure who to believe; and they are certainly not sure who should lead them. Yet we are supposed to take seriously comments on health policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have only a minute to go.
—I think I have two, if Senator Newman can count.

—I listened to Senator Newman and when it comes to saying nothing, she is an expert. She has to be because she does not have a policy. On the other hand, the government that created Medicare has it as the basis of health policy, and we are proud of it. The only thing that I would seek to do, would be to add to it. Certainly, after 10 years, I am not saying that everything is perfect. If there are something like 30,000 Australians waiting for longer than six months, I think that is inappropriate and it is something that we should work on. It is worth acknowledging that that is something the whole of government in Australia—the federal government, the state governments, which run the hospitals, and the Commonwealth government—should address. Next week when there is a meeting of health ministers in Perth, we will be addressing some of the issues.

PARA.TAB: As I said in question time, we need to address the numbers, distribution and training of surgeons because that, at least in part, does it. We will be spending $25 million a year over the next four years, which we will be directing to making sure that the numbers on waiting lists go down and that some patients, who were not going to be dealt with otherwise, are dealt with now in a hurry. That is tangible evidence of what we are doing. But in the opposition's case, it cannot even agree on whether or not to abolish bulk-billing or how much of it. No-one has a clue what Senator Newman is talking about because she does not have a clue herself. If she does not have a clue, what she ought to do is get one and get one fast.

TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —Basically, this motion deals with an issue that is not terribly popular—that is, to have a good health care system, we have to spend money. We have to acknowledge that there will be a greater demand from the public for us to meet community needs—particularly needs that are forever expanding in the health area as more technology and more diagnostic methods and tests become available—and we have to meet a lot of that demand.

PARA.TAB: The opposition is basically arguing that the private health system is the way to go. The Australian Democrats argue, `Yes, we have a private system and it has a place'. Many of the needs that have now been identified will not be met by private health insurance, but some of them need the cooperation of the private health insurance industry. In particular, some of the recommendations in the Burdekin report see a role for both the private and the public system.
I will quote some of the recommendations of the Burdekin report and ask Senator Newman where the money will come from for many of them. One of the recommendations in chapter 5 states:

SPEECH.PARA: Federal, State and Territory governments should provide increased funding and resources to integrate mental health services as a matter of urgency. In the first instance Governments must give priority to redirecting funding from high cost institutions to such services.
Governments should accord a high priority to improving inter-agency and inter-sectoral co-operation and coordination.
All of that will cost money. One of the recommendations in chapter six states:

The Federal Government, in consultation with State and Territory Governments, service providers, mental health professionals and allied staff, and people with mental awareness should develop and implement national standards concerning the regulation and maintenance of psychiatric care and treatment.
It goes on to state:

The Federal Government, in consultation with State and Territory Governments and service providers should examine and clarify the treatment roles of mental health professionals and allied staff working both in institutions and in the community. In particular, the roles of psychiatrists and clinical psychologists should be carefully assessed to ensure the most effective utilisation of professional services.
Finally, it states:
The role of mental health professionals and allied staff in the delivery of community-based services must be adequately recognised by the Federal government in Medicare funding.

I turn from the many recommendations in the Burdekin report to look at Aboriginal health, which the AMA, the minister, and the opposition, along with the Democrats, have all acknowledged to be an area of high priority—an area that has to be addressed in this year's budget. In the most recent copy of Australian Medicine, 21 February 1994, the President of the AMA said:

The unmet need for health care in Aboriginal Australia is staggering. Everywhere I looked I found services desperately under-resourced in both a human and financial way. The low morale of many Aboriginal health workers was disturbing.
Page 186 of the most recent Medical Journal of Australia states:

In 1991, at the First National Rural Health Conference in Toowoomba, convened by the Rural Doctors Association of Australia, a workshop on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander health called for attention to education and training for Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal professionals and the full implementation of the recommendations of the National Aboriginal Health Strategy Working Party Report.

I ask Senator Newman again: where will this money come from? Perhaps the opposition may say, `Cut something; redirect money from somewhere else within the health budget'. If it is going to say that, let it identify where we can make savings. What areas are we supposed to be cutting to provide the money that is needed in these two areas alone?

PARA.TAB: Moving on, we can see the needs, which have already been talked about today by the two previous speakers, of the public hospital system. Increasing some coverage by the private health insurance industry—and even the minister's own package—will do little but put a floor under the number of people leaving private health insurance. It will do nothing for the unmet needs that already exist, particularly in the areas of infrastructure spending, the provision of new pieces of equipment, the upgrading of existing hospitals and the provision of hospital beds to the outlying suburbs in our larger cities.

I go back again to some of Senator Newman's earlier arguments that somehow by supporting the private health insurance industry everything will be fixed. I suggest to Senator Newman that what we really should be fixing is the private health insurance industry itself. We have just had a period in this country where industry after industry has been encouraged to modernise and to reform. Micro-economic reform was one of catchcries and one of the common terms we heard. The private health insurance industry somehow seems to have missed out. If we look at its profit performance we see a steadily increasing level of profit and virtually no effort whatsoever at more efficient, effective practices; no effort to be more accountable; and, if we listen to some of the private hospitals, no real effort to meet their changing needs to ensure different procedures are carried out in different ways to ensure shorter periods of stay in hospital. This applies right across the board in a variety of private hospitals. I refer particularly to the need to change insurance practices for mental health.

Senator Newman's urgency motion today referred to `causing even greater damage to private health insurance'. I want to stress that I believe it is the private health insurance industry itself that is damaging private health insurance. People and families are actually voting with their feet now. They have done their sums. They see that if they put that money in the bank then they have a chance each year to afford quite a number of days in a private hospital—and indeed if their condition were any more serious they would end up in a public hospital anyway. So they are actually making a quite rational decision to leave private health insurance.

I suggest that the private health insurance industry, instead of sitting around and believing in the cargo cult that somehow the government is going to come to its rescue and maybe give tax deductibility, which would ensure its profits for several years before people started complaining again about increased premiums, should be looking at getting its own house in order. It should become more competitive. It should be offering a far wider variety of insurance options. It should be listening not just to members of the public who are voting with their feet but to doctors and particularly the private hospitals which are asking for different types of cover and different types of support.

We have to get back to the basic question of where the money is coming from. As I said when I began, talking about an increase in taxation is not terribly popular. But we have to acknowledge that this Medicare levy is already far short of the mark. It does not cover anything like the full amount drawn out of the tax purse to fund Medicare.

TALK.START.PARA: —Only 17 per cent.

—Perhaps as we look at the small percentage—only 17 per cent, thank you, Senator Herron—we should be asking government to be more open and a little more honest. Perhaps we should transfer from that general tax paid column of our income tax return the full and correct amount to the Medicare column. Perhaps in that way pressure would come from members of the public for the government to be a little more accountable in terms of where their money is going. I think, if the community realised how much it is already paying for Medicare through the tax system, we would have a number of areas that the government would need to check again, to be a little more open and a little more public about.

PARA.TAB: I cannot finish today in the two minutes I have remaining without asking the minister how he thinks his package of reforms is going to do anything whatsoever to help the public system. I note the minister today claimed that he does have Labor Party support, perhaps that suggests that the committee which is just about to report, I understand, is wasting its time. Perhaps all those people who sent submissions and took a lot of time and effort to make comments on his package have indeed wasted their time.

If the minister was still with us, I would ask him to explain where the government's priorities are. He seems to have made a 180-degree shift to start calling for an increase in the Medicare levy while on the one hand having this package very much alive, with some $9 1/2 million already spent on it. What exactly is the minister doing? Is he preparing the way for somebody else to take over the portfolio? If he is, we may be beginning all over again with a totally new package, perhaps with no increase in the Medicare levy and perhaps with something that we have absolutely no notion of as we debate this today.

So in conclusion I would just like to ask again: is this motion today referring to all Australians when it refers to `causing even greater damage to the health care of all Australians'? If we mean all Australians, surely we include those with mental illness and Aboriginal Australians. We really do need to look quite honestly and openly at where the money is coming from if it is not going to come out of the Medicare levy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I listened with interest to Senator Richardson's contribution. I noted the headings under which he spoke, and I would like to quickly run through them. In his 10 minutes he talked about the Fremantle by-election, he talked about the leadership of the Liberal Party, he talked about Mrs Bronwyn Bishop, he attacked Senator Newman for bringing this matter up, he attacked the Liberal Party's policy at the last election, he attacked the spokesperson for Senator Newman, and then finally, just as a little throwaway line, he talked about increasing the number of surgeons and some agreement with the health ministers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Richardson did not reply to one point raised—not one. He did not even attempt to, because he would have been defending the indefensible. It was his usual puffed up, self-important arrogance that he goes on with when trying to defend something. His best defence is attack. The reality is that we know what has occurred in relation to this country with regard to the health system: there has been a deliberate policy of rationing. No more money as a percentage of gross domestic product has been spent on health care in the last 13 years—no more at all. We have rationing in the community, and he talks about the small percentage on waiting lists. Of course there is a small percentage on waiting lists because doctors are so busy doing the acute work that has to be done—anybody who develops a cancer in this country gets precedence.

I left work in a public hospital in Queensland three years ago. Since then—and I questioned the hospital about this the other day—the waiting list has extended out further and further because the poor people who do not question the system get put on the end of the list. I would cringe when I was there and have to say to a poor pensioner, `I am sorry, you have to wait 18 months for your operation'. Does anyone know what the pensioner would say? The pensioner would say, `Thank you, doctor'. Some were so grateful to have something done that they did not question the system. They thought that was their lot. I got angry when that happened.

The great self-important, puffed up Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) says, `Not a problem, there is only 3 per cent or only 1 per cent'. What would you say, Mr Acting Deputy President, if you were the one that was waiting four years, as they do now at the Royal Brisbane Hospital, for a hip replacement because it costs so much and because there is rationing going on? You would be aware, Mr Acting Deputy President, that the nurses were on strike in Queensland last week because they find the system as it exists is intolerable. The dear nurses, the ones who have been sweat labour for so long, were out on strike last week because of the system. This is the system the comments on which Senator Richardson did not reply to. He talked about bulk-billing as if bulk-billing was introduced by the Labor Party. Bulk-billing was introduced by the medical profession a hundred years ago; no pensioner was ever charged. Anybody who had difficulty in paying their medical bills—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not true.

—It is correct. People were not charged if they could not afford it. The doctors in the hospitals were honorary; they were not paid. Now government senators are implying that this is some great Labor Party system that has been brought in. It was brought in a hundred years ago.
—Are we going back to that?

—Nobody is suggesting that. Rationing has nothing to do with politics; it is because of the ageing of the population and because of the technology that has been brought in. It is useless to say that it will be solved by increasing the Medicare levy. If the Medicare levy is increased it will affect the lower income earners and the middle income earners the most. I have the figures here: the low and middle income earners actually provide 40 per cent to 50 per cent of what comes out of the Medicare levy. It is another tax and it affects the lower and middle—

PARA.TAB: Senator Crowley interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Because the wealthier people are carrying their own insurance. Those opposite don't understand that because they have not got the wit to understand it. They do not understand their own system.

PARA.TAB: You, Mr Acting Deputy President, would be aware that the largest public hospital in the Southern Hemisphere is the Royal Brisbane Hospital. It needs $100 million to bring its infrastructure up to modern day standards. There is even a report going around which says that the best way to handle it is to knock it down and start again. The chronic underfunding of the infrastructure of hospitals has been brought about by this government. It has had 10 years to do something about this situation. What has it done? Nothing—not a single thing. I was appalled when I saw the burns unit at the Royal Brisbane Hospital the other day. It was there when I was a resident 30 years ago. This is an example of the great system that is providing capital infrastructure.

The government's own great Dr Deeble, the architect of Medicare, said that the private system was part of Medicare. If ever there was a solecism, that was—to bring it around full belt. The government has destroyed the private hospital system. The number of people who are insured has gone down to something like 70 per cent of the total number insured when this government took office.

Part of the crisis management—Senator Richardson calls it reform; it is further destruction—includes increasing the Medicare levy and taxing the poor. The poor will opt out even further. Fewer than 30 per cent of people in Queensland are privately insured but, because of the poor services that are provided there, last year 22,000 extra people took out private insurance. They are defying the rest of the country.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a lot to catch up on.

—Yes, the hospitals have a long way to go before they catch up to where they should be. Look at the palace we are in; people come here and visit us and see these magnificent surroundings. When we compare the public hospital beds that I have seen in Queensland, where people are stuck if they get sick, with the luxury that we have here, we should hang our heads in shame. We spent $1,000 million on this building yet we do not spend $100 million on the largest public hospital in the Southern Hemisphere. That is what the government is proposing.
—Pathetic.

—That hospital is pathetic. I am pleased that Senator Crowley supports me in that respect. I am glad that she has been to that hospital and looked at it, because she would not have made that statement if she had not. It is pathetic. What has been done about the other problems that exist? Health insurance premiums have gone up by over 100 per cent in the past seven years. The increase has significantly outstripped the growth in the CPI.

PARA.TAB: The great, puffed-up, self-important Senator Richardson is going to cure the Aboriginal health problem. He got his photograph on the front page of the paper. I saw him on a major program talking about how he was going to cure the Aboriginal health problem. The life expectancy of Aboriginal females is 15 years less than the non-Aboriginal average. The life expectancy of Aboriginal males is 22 years less than the non-Aboriginal average. What is Senator Richardson going to do about it? I will call him to account each year I am here and ask him what he has done. He is grandstanding; he is always grandstanding. He takes whatever photo opportunity he can.

He was going to do a lot about breast cancer. Honourable senators will remember that breast cancer was the big thing on his agenda. What has he done in the past 12 months? He has put out press releases. That is just marvellous. Now he has taken up the issue of Aboriginal health. What is he going to do about the life expectancy of Aboriginals in his time? The infant mortality rate of Aboriginals is two and a half to three and a half times that of non-Aboriginals. Let him talk about how he has improved that situation in 12 months time.

Finally, as I mentioned in the summary before, he is going to get an agreement to increase the number of surgeons—something along those lines. It takes 15 years to train a surgeon, taking into account the undergraduate period of time, the hospital standing and nine years of post-hospital employment. So a great thing that will be. There is already an oversupply of general surgeons in the community and there is an oversupply of general practitioners. Maldistribution is the problem, as honourable senators know. Here Senator Richardson goes again—off around the world. He did not answer a question. He did not answer the substantive argument; he did not even try to because it is indefensible.

The Labor Party's answer is more tax. Senator Richardson calls it a levy. It is a tax by any other name. The jobs levy and the Medicare levy are just taxes. The Labor Party's answer is to increase tax and throw more money at the problem. Look at what has happened in relation to the Aboriginal community in that regard: 257,000 people in the country have gone backwards because more money has been thrown at them—over $1,000 million a year. There needs to be fundamental reform, which is our policy. Senator Richardson said that we do not have a policy. Our policy has gone through the shadow ministry and the Policy Review Committee, and it is supported. It is fairly straightforward. We have done away with some aspects, but our policy stands.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —First, I would like to answer the point that Senator Herron has been making about the health system in Queensland. I remind people that for many years the Queensland health system was in the hands of a government with which for most of that time Senator Herron's party was in coalition. That government allowed the health system to run down, just as nearly every service for people in Queensland was run down.
—It was working well then.
—I will argue that at another stage; I do not want to waste time doing so now. This motion refers to:

SPEECH.PARA: The intention of the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, to increase the Medicare levy, thereby breaking yet another of the Government's election promises, and causing even greater damage to private health insurance and the health care of all Australians.

The motion immediately triggers the question: is it the intention of the Minister for Health (Senator Richardson) to raise the levy? I think the wording of the motion betrays the lack of knowledge of the opposition—possibly including Senator Newman—about how decisions are made in the government. This decision would be part of the budget, so it must be a part of a cabinet decision—as all decisions are—based on discussion with cabinet subcommittees and with caucus, and informed by discussions and consultations with and feedback from the community.

PARA.TAB: The feedback that I am getting in my office and as I travel around Victoria, which I am passing on, is that most people have no argument with raising the levy, as long as it is applied progressively to income; in other words, it is not necessarily hitting the poor, as Senator Herron and others have suggested it would. Such a rise, indeed, might lessen the need for private health insurance. But would that necessarily be a negative? People do not have to have private insurance. I, like many Australians, choose not to have private health cover, although I do have cover for services not covered by Medicare, such as dental care. I would hope that some of the health services which are at present outside Medicare might be able to be included if funding were increased.

It was accepted by a review of Medicare benefits undertaken in the mid-1980s that services covered should be expanded if the funding were available. I will mention one such service—and Senator Lees has already referred to it—and that is clinical psychology. As a counselling psychologist before I entered parliament, I often unwillingly had to refer patients for psychiatric treatment when their needs would have been better met by a clinical psychologist—but then they would have had to pay the full charge.

If we want to cut hospital waiting lists and improve service provision, particularly in states like Victoria, where the present state government is cutting services, there is a need to give greater support to service provision for all Australians, not just those who can afford to take out private insurance. So I am much more concerned about possible damage to the health care of Australians than I am about possible damage to private health insurance.

The aim of our government is to improve the health care of all Australians. In my view, this is more likely to be enhanced by the maintenance of the services available to all Australians, whether or not they can afford it and/or whether or not they choose to have private health cover. If that maintenance necessitates an increase in the Medicare levy, that is surely preferable to the alternative which seems to be implied in this motion; that is, that people should pay for private insurance rather than pay more for Medicare.

I point out that private funds do not charge according to income, as the Medicare levy does, and they do not scale their contributions according to a member's ability to pay. I personally would have no problems with an increased levy on higher income earners, such as all of us in this chamber, should a decision be made to raise the income ceiling so that the percentage of income going to the levy becomes more equitable by increasing it as income increases.

It is precisely because we are keeping our election promises that there may be a need for some increase in the levy for some of us. Some of those promises now being implemented are the inclusion in Medicare of bone densitometry for people at risk of osteoporosis, a dental program for health card holders and an additional $57.7 million over the next four years for palliative care, to cite just a few examples. This is in stark contrast to opposition policies at the time of the election, exactly one year ago, as Senator Richardson has said.

It was my experience during that campaign, particularly in opposition held country electorates, that it was the opposition health policies, including its Medicare policies, which together with the GST were turning voters away from it in droves. These were often voters from its own traditional base. I speak of country Victoria. This was particularly so in relatively isolated rural areas without access to community health centres, an initiative of a previous Labor government in the 1970s, or public hospital facilities. These facilities, of course, are shrinking rapidly in Victoria under the Kennett government.

From talking to people when I have been overseas, to overseas visitors in this country and particularly to migrants coming from overseas, it is continually emphasised to me that we are the envy of most other countries for the security of health cover available to us through Medicare. The standards of health care provision are also impressive, particularly in the public hospital system, but the big difference between the Australian system and the systems in most other countries is that it is available universally and available on the basis of need.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about Germany, France and the United Kingdom? Health care is available universally.

—I do not have time to go into that, but that is not entirely so. I have one daughter living in the UK and my son lived in Germany for many years and I would argue that that is not so. I think we are very fortunate in the level of care we can offer and that we can offer it to all Australians. I urge senators to heed the needs of their constituents and vote against this motion.

—I rise to support my colleagues Senator Newman and Senator Herron in this urgency motion. I would have thought the Minister for Health, Senator Richardson, besides needing to be in the chamber for this important debate, would have been far more measured in his boast at question time that we have the best health system going, considering his most public embarrassment about and condemnation of the health system with regard to Aboriginal health. His parading on the national media hardly led the public of Australia to believe that the minister at least thought we have the best health system. Clearly, the minister was trying to get the message across that we do not.

PARA.TAB: As a nation we may be able to do better, but it is startling to say the least that this government has just woken up to the fact that we have a problem with Aboriginal health services. Senator Richardson is trying to tell us that, after 11 years with the portfolio, the government has just woken up to this problem, as properly outlined by Senator Herron. Amongst Aborigines, infant mortality is 3 1/2 times higher than the average, female life expectancy is some 15 years fewer than the average, there are problems with sanitary living conditions and with the personnel needed to support this particular community. Moreover, there is concern about maladministration and about the resources being directed to and arriving for Aboriginal people's needs.

I think it would have been far more helpful, if not worthy, for the minister to address this urgency motion directly during his contribution instead of, as Senator Herron properly outlined, merely delving into political irrelevancies, mentioning the Fremantle by-election and Mrs Bishop and attacking Senator Newman and the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson.

These matters are political irrelevancies. It was very easy for Senator Richardson to do that, but he failed to address in his responsible position one of the most basic and serious needs of Australian families. To that end, Australian families have every reason to be concerned about the upcoming May budget and what tax increases lie ahead for them, considering it has only been some nine months since the last budget was brought down with its new array of taxes visited upon Australian households. Not content with those tax increases which directly influence those households, the minister is now suggesting that in the May budget the Medicare levy should be increased from 1.4 per cent to two per cent—a 40 per cent increase.

Senator Richardson has set this issue running. If it were not for the string of by-elections we are now facing, it would be all but policy in the May budget. However, with the array of by-elections before us, the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) has felt somewhat obliged to deny such an increase. As unconvincing as it is, it has set the stage for an increase in the Medicare levy. That is nothing short of another slug for the Australian people. It is a regressive tax upon the lower and middle income families of Australia. Simply notching up the Medicare levy to meet the country's health crisis is no solution.
Senator Zakharov interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Zakharov interrupts me. I have to pick up something that Senator Zakharov tried to sell this chamber. She said that she has toured country Victoria and knows the health concerns of country Victoria. I challenge Senator Zakharov to tell us the last time she was in country Victoria and who accepted her in country Victoria. Take it from me—a Victorian National Party senator—that her name is not known, that she is not seen and nor does she care about the concerns of country people in Victoria.

PARA.TAB: Our problems go deeper than simply proposing a new tax to fund our health system. We have to produce a policy framework for this nation's long-term and immediate health problems. Senator Richardson has many critics of any proposal he has put before cabinet and out in society to restructure the health care system. He has the AHA and the Australian Private Hospitals Association on his back. This senator is taking on all the connotations of being the Hillary Clinton of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —Usually when people talk about the silly season they mean Christmas. However, the silly season in parliament and in these circles is the pre-budget run-up. That has been exemplified and well proven today. Again, the opposition is trotting out the same old matters of public importance and urgency motions. Nothing new has come from the opposition—not a single thing. It is 12 months to the day, or one day over, since the opposition's policies were soundly defeated. People certainly had their say as to what they thought about the policies the opposition went to the last election with.
—One day since they were trounced in Fremantle.

—My word. So 12 months later, the people of Fremantle reinforced what the people of Australia thought and said then about the opposition's health policies. What have we got from the opposition on health since then? We have had slight changes. Dr Hewson has said that the opposition's previous policy had been health funding and not health care and that he wanted the opposition to move towards health care. However, we have seen nothing from the opposition. We have heard some conflicting evidence today. Mrs Bishop commented yesterday and Senator Newman said today that she had got some of it wrong.

PARA.TAB: That is a very interesting comment. We still do not know what the opposition's health policy is.
