PARA.TAB: Having said that, the Democrats today welcome the statement of the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) on the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia and the detail he has presented on the current status of the issue as far as the government is concerned. In particular we welcome the minister's endorsement of the principles underlying Australia's longstanding policy of multiculturalism.

Over the last few decades multiculturalism has been a central philosophy in Australia. Since 1977, when the Australian Democrats were formed, we have been strong supporters of multicultural policies, and we reiterate that support today. As the minister said in his statement, we should pride ourselves that multiculturalism has been a success story in this country.

Against this background it is most unfortunate that in recent weeks we have witnessed the various acts of vandalism and other forms of attack against both communities and their properties, particularly in Melbourne and Canberra. Such attacks are totally unacceptable, and the Democrats sincerely hope that the legal and judicial processes in this country will be able to run their full course in relation to these deplorable events.

The Democrats join with others on both sides of this chamber, including Senator Short, who has just spoken, in pleading with leaders of both communities and, in fact, all of us to calm down to help attempts to reduce the tensions which now exist over this issue. We should remember that we are Australians first. The sorts of violent actions we have witnessed in recent weeks are, if anything, absolutely not Australian.

If ever an issue involved shades of grey, the current dispute over the Former Yugoslav Republic of Macedonia is it. In recent months all Democrat senators, and I am sure most of us in here, have been bombarded with reams of correspondence over this issue. Much of it has been written in a style and language that has been far from helpful or constructive. I believe that in this issue, like in many other disputes of similar dimensions, the correspondents could have assisted themselves and their case if they had been prepared to recognise at least that no one issue is as black or as white as they like to believe or as they want others to believe. It would be helpful if, as the minister suggests, members of both communities attempted to look at this contentious issue from each other's perspective.

The Australian Democrats join with the government in stating our belief that there is certainly a measure of right and justice on both sides of this dispute. We would all do well to remember that no-one has a total monopoly on truth. I for one was intrigued to learn from the minister that responsible community leaders from both sides have privately been prepared to acknowledge that fact. That is very encouraging. It is interesting to know that this is the case, and perhaps it helps to explain the motivation behind some statements in recent days, although we again urge community leaders to exercise such a view more forcefully in public statements which they are making.

We welcome the content and the general thrust of the minister's statement. We believe it is appropriately well-balanced and the government is to be commended for that approach. We are hopeful that the statement will clarify issues for all Australians in a positive and helpful way. In the meantime the Democrats keenly await the outcome of the considerations currently being given by the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, Senator Bolkus, on how community relations resources might be better utilised in reducing current community tensions in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to address tonight the serious issue of superannuation, a matter which I have monitored for some time, and in particular certain superannuation funds in Queensland. The new Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 provides the legislative framework for prudential supervision of the superannuation industry. It is designed to increase the prudential control and protection of superannuation funds and strengthen the security of superannuation savings. An important aspect of these prudential controls is disclosure of information about individual funds. It is information disclosure, or more precisely the lack of information disclosure, under existing and proposed regulation that is the issue I wish to address.

PARA.TAB: In the first report of the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation, Safeguarding super, the committee acknowledges the importance of information disclosure in prudential supervision. It suggests that, while the information disclosure requirements under OSSA have improved, information disclosure could be further improved by increasing the amount of information publicly available.

Under the current OSSA regulations, trustees are required to disclose financial and other information to their members and beneficiaries but have no obligation to disclose any information to third parties, with the exception of regulatory bodies. While the ISC is permitted to publish statistical information relating to superannuation funds, it is expressly prohibited from identifying individual funds and disclosing information about those funds. Thus under OSSA, information about individual funds is not publicly available.

In its first report, the Senate committee suggests that greater investor protection and public awareness of superannuation will be facilitated by requiring disclosure of funds' investment strategies and financial statements to the public at large. Such disclosure would enable analyses by industry experts, the financial community and the media. The committee therefore recommended that the ISC create and maintain a database so that financial press and industry experts could report independently on superannuation funds with arms-length members.

The government's response to recommendation 4.13 is to accept it with modification. The response indicates that access to information could be achieved by extending accessibility to the public access database already being developed by the ISC in the context of the superannuation guarantee arrangements. Such accessibility is, however, qualified by the statement that:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the provision of detailed information as recommended by the Committee may need to be restricted to large funds on the basis of efficiency and cost.

That is a very serious problem. The intention to restrict public access to information relating to large funds would work directly against the very reason for the committee recommending public disclosure, which was:
evidence presented to the Committee indicates that problems are more likely to arise in small funds.

It may be expected that the reason for the tendency of small funds to have more problems is that they have a lower public profile and that their members have limited expertise and resources to assess the performance of their fund. Large funds are more likely to already be under public scrutiny and their members and members' representatives are more likely to have more resources and greater access to expert superannuation advice. It is therefore important that the information be available without restriction, provided that information about individual fund members is not disclosed.

PARA.TAB: The puzzling question is: how does the government propose to give effect to this recommendation, with or without modification, when the SIS act specifically precludes the ISC from disclosing any information which will individually identify a superannuation fund? That is, section 348 of the SIS act is basically the same as section 19 of OSSA in that the ISC is prohibited from publishing any statistical information which would identify an individual superannuation fund and disclose information about it. The SIS act is clearly restrictive and inadequate by excluding third parties from accessing information about individual superannuation funds via the ISC.

The government acknowledges that increased scrutiny of funds is an important safeguard for members. During the public information seminars on the proposed SIS bills held last year, the former Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer, Mr Gary Johns, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: Greater member participation means wider scrutiny of a fund's operations, consistent with the notion that the greater the number of watchful eyes, the smaller the risk of undetected fraud or negligence.

While Mr Johns was referring to the SIS bills' requirements for equal representation on the funds' board of trustees, the idea that wider scrutiny equates with greater member protection means that, with public disclosure of information, even more eyes are watching, including expert eyes, thus significantly strengthening the safeguards of members' assets against negligent loss or fraud.

PARA.TAB: Disclosure to the public at large will go a long way towards enhancing prudential control of superannuation funds which will, in turn, benefit members in at least three ways. Firstly, although industry, financial experts and the media cannot possibly scrutinise the operation of every fund, analyses of the performance of samples of funds by various industry groupings will provide members of all funds with some benchmarks against which to evaluate the performance of their own fund and assess how successful or otherwise their fund has been in comparison with industry standards. In the absence of publication of funds' financial information, no such comparisons are possible. Secondly, if fund trustees know that the financial statements and other information about the operation of their funds are open to public scrutiny, they have an added incentive to ensure that the fund is operating efficiently and effectively. Improved efficiency flows on as a cost saving to members. Thirdly, the knowledge that they are under public scrutiny will also provide trustees with a disincentive to neglect their fiduciary duties or act dishonestly to the detriment of fund members.

An argument against additional disclosure is the associated cost. However, the evidence presented to the Senate committee clearly indicates that there is a need for wider disclosure, and the benefits that members will derive from such disclosure will outweigh the costs. The requirement for public disclosure of information may also help to overcome the reluctance of some fund trustees to disclose information to members under existing rules; that is, both under OSSA regulations and the forthcoming SIS regulations.

A case in point is the current situation with former members of the Queensland Professional Officers Association Superannuation Fund. The Senate select committee held an inquiry into the QPOASF and presented its findings in the committee's 8th annual report in August 1993. The inquiry centred around the extraordinary payments made in early 1987 to Messrs Martindale—who was also a trustee at that time—Daly, Rutherford and Buchanan and Ms Kinder. Given that these extraordinary payments were contrary to the terms of the fund's trust deed, the committee found that the trustees had possibly breached trust laws.

Towers Perrin, who were engaged by the QPOA to investigate the extraordinary withdrawals, reported that the fund had suffered a detriment of $34,304 due to the extraordinary withdrawals. To overcome this detriment, one of the sponsoring employers, the QPOA, has made a payment to a special fund to make good the shortfall. Although the committee's inquiry was hindered by the inability of the QPOASF, National Mutual, the funds' administrator or relevant Queensland authorities to produce the original documents which authorised the extraordinary payments, it is clear that the payments were outside the terms of the trust deed and the funds suffered a detriment as a result. The committee also found that fund members had insufficient notice or knowledge of the funds, accounts and trustees' decisions.

The outcome of the inquiry has no doubt raised questions in the minds of past and present members of the fund about their entitlements and benefits, including such questions as: were my superannuation benefits affected by the detriment, and, if so, how; am I entitled to my portion of the additional funds contributed by the QPOA? These are important questions.

Difficulties experienced by some former QPOASF members in their attempts to get answers to questions demonstrates the inadequacy of the disclosure rules governing superannuation funds in the past and present under OSSA regulations and possibly in the future under the new SIS regime. One individual who was a member of this fund from 1985 to 1990 was concerned whether the benefits paid to him were correct and whether he had any further entitlement. Under the provisions of OSSA regulation 17(1)(i), he requested the present trustees and National Mutual—the fund administrator—to provide him with copies of any actuary reports, auditor reports, financial statements and ISC documents relating to the fund for the relevant years and details of any surpluses that were distributed to him during his period of fund membership.

The individual first wrote to the QPOASF trustees and then National Mutual in June 1993. National Mutual responded by stating that it could not release the information without the authorisation of the trustees. The QPOASF trustees' response was that they were seeking guidance from the ISC. So it went round in circles.

In September 1993, having had no further response, the individual again wrote to the fund trustees advising that he would lodge a complaint with the ISC if the requested information were not received within a few weeks. The trustees' response was that they were still waiting for advice from the ISC. The member lodged a complaint with the ISC in November 1993. Two weeks later, the ISC wrote to the member advising that it had written to the fund seeking its help in obtaining copies of the member's yearly statements—no reference to the information which he had requested. Honourable senators would probably not be surprised if I told them that the member is still waiting.

This continued stonewalling by the fund's trustees leaves the individual in an invidious position with nowhere to go. The ISC seems powerless to help. Can we be confident that the sanctions against trustees encompassed in the new legislation will prevent recurrence of such blatant disregard of members' rights?

Another former member wrote to the same fund requesting that, in light of the detriment suffered by the fund in 1987 and the additional contributions by the QPOA to make up the shortfall, the benefits of all former members be re-examined to ensure that the distribution be made fairly and equitably to all past and present members. The QPOA passed the request to National Mutual and its response stated that, in accordance with the Towers Perrin findings, the detriment arising from the 1987 extraordinary payments was suffered by members who had participated in the 1991 surplus distribution.

As that individual ceased to be a member in 1989, supposedly he was not affected. However, National Mutual does not attempt to explain why it is the members who participated in the 1991 surplus distribution who suffered the detriment and not the members who participated in the 1988 distribution. It seems logical that, if a detriment has occurred because of extraordinary payments out of the fund in 1987, this detriment would affect the very next distribution made by the fund, which was in 1988. In a letter of 27 May 1993 from National Mutual to the committee, Mr Peter Grace states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Reserve Accumulation was distributed in accordance with the trust deed following the annual review of the Fund in 1988 and under the terms of the Deed was to be reviewed again within three years i.e. following the 1991 annual review.

So if there was a detriment at the time of the 1991 distribution, did that detriment also not exist at the time of the 1988 distribution? Or has the detriment skipped one distribution to appear in the next by some actuarial sleight of hand? Perhaps the information from National Mutual is incorrect and there was no distribution in 1988. It is quite a puzzle indeed.

PARA.TAB: The problems that these two individuals are experiencing raise a number of questions which need answers. Unfortunately, the QPOASF trustees and their advisers appear unwilling to provide answers or the information that the members need to help them answer the questions for themselves. The only way that these former members have any hope of satisfying themselves that they have not been financially disadvantaged is to obtain copies of the fund's financial statements, actuarial reports and other relevant documentation and seek professional assistance in unravelling what has transpired in the administration of the fund between 1987 and 1991.

At the time that they were members of the fund they were entitled to have access to that information under the disclosure rules of the OSSA regulations. When they were members, however, they had no inkling of what had occurred in 1987 and thus had no cause to seek out the information. Several years later they now suspect that they have been financially disadvantaged but are unable to gain access to information to which they clearly have a legal and moral right. So we can see the problem which is faced.

These circumstances give rise to a fundamental question that the government needs to address. Are the information disclosure rules under the forthcoming SIS regulations adequate to ensure that individuals who have a legitimate interest in the operation of a superannuation fund have access to such information? It is suggested that the easiest and most cost-effective way of preventing a repeat of the saga I have described is to accept the

SPEECH.PARA: Senate select committee's recommendations without modification and publish information about all arms-length superannuation funds.

PARA.TAB: Finally, I indicate that I will be sending a copy of this speech to Mr Pooley, the ISC Commissioner, requesting that he instruct his officers preparing the SIS regulations to take account of the points that I have made, especially the need for former fund members to have access to fund documents prepared during the currency of their membership. I will be closely scrutinising the regulations, which I understand will be tabled in the Senate during the next few months. If they do not come up to scratch, I will not rule out moving that they be referred to the Senate Select Committee on Superannuation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

(5) Has there been any reduction in the training and experience requirements for aircraft maintenance personnel in the past 5 years; if so, why.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question, based on advice provided by the Civil Aviation Authority:

PARA.TAB: (1) It is assumed that the honourable senator's question is directed at the application for the extension of the Permissible Unserviceability for the inoperative autopilot of VH-NDU. The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has advised that Permissible Unserviceabilities are approved under Civil Aviation Regulation 37 and do not require a concession application. The CAA is not aware of any other concession application around this time. The request was made on Monarch Aviation Group letterhead dated 14 May 1993 and was signed by Mr R W McLean. A copy of the request is attached.

(2) Assuming the honourable senator is referring to the application for the extension of the Permissible Unserviceability, a further Permissible Unserviceability for the inoperative autopilot on aircraft VH-NDU was issued on 14 May 1993. That approval merely gave approval to continuing to operate that aircraft with an `Inoperative Autopilot'. That approval did not authorise or otherwise permit the deactivation of `associated equipment', nor did it authorise operation of VH-NDU with any items of equipment, including the autopilot, being removed from the aircraft. If approval to operate with deactivated `associated equipment' was required by Monarch, a separate application for a Permissible Unserviceability in those cases would have to have been made. No such application was made and no such approval was granted. If Monarch had wished to operate with equipment removed, they would have had to apply pursuant to Civil Aviation Regulation 42U for approval by the Authority and be authorised pursuant to Civil Aviation Regulation 35 to operate with that equipment removed. No such application was made to the Authority and no such approval was granted.

(3) (a) Investigation by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI) revealed that the main standby inverter had been removed from the incident aircraft for fitment to another aircraft. This occurred at the end of a shift and the maintenance crew did not document the action nor give a formal handover to the oncoming shift to ensure that a replacement standby inverter was fitted. The lack of the inverter was not detected during flight crew pre-flight checks in Sydney, but was detected during those checks prior to departure from Los Angeles. Safety deficiencies concerning both the shift handover procedures and flight deck checklist procedures have been identified and safety recommendations made to rectify them.

(3) (b) An Eastern Airlines Dash 8 aircraft (VH-TQO) departed Tamworth for Sydney on 10 November 1993. Engineering at Tamworth had performed maintenance on the landing gear overnight. Immediately after take-off, the `weight on wheels' caution light illuminated in the aircraft, and later, during the flight, the ground spoilers (or lift dumpers) deployed when the throttles were retarded.

Investigation in Sydney found that the `weight on wheels' switches were out of adjustment. It appears that the switches had not been adjusted after landing gear torque links were changed the previous night.

The ground spoiler incident involved the failure of a Licensed Aircraft Maintenance Engineer (LAME) to follow the Dash 8 Maintenance Procedures. Hence, the `weight on wheels' sensors were not adjusted after the links were changed. This in turn caused the aircraft to sense ground mode when in the air, so that when the throttles were retarded the ground spoilers extended.

(4) The CAA has advised that some officers within the Directorate of Aviation Safety Regulation (DASR) have expressed the view that it would be more appropriate for the safety regulatory function to be separated out from the Authority. The CAA has made it clear that the primary function of the Directorate is the regulation of aviation safety.

(5) There have been no changes to the training requirements for Aircraft Maintenance Engineers (AMEs) in the past five years. However, prior to 1988, AMEs were required to complete a Schedule of Experience (SOE) which was specified by the then Department. In 1988, the Civil Aviation Orders were amended to permit operators of high capacity Regular Public Transport (RPT) aircraft to produce their own SOEs for their LAMEs.

These SOEs were subject to approval by the CAA. Early in 1993, the CAA reviewed this system and, as a result of that review, it was decided to re-introduce the requirement for AMEs employed by high capacity RPT operators to complete SOEs published by the CAA. The new CAA SOE was made available to the industry in early November 1993.
Those AMEs employed in general aviation have always been required to complete a CAA published SOE.

(6) Around 10,000 accidents and incidents were reported in the three year period from 1991 to November 1993. Therefore, it was not considered practical to provide a description of each occurrence, even for those considered as serious. However, BASI's data on accidents and incidents are presented in a manner that provides information on the relative seriousness of occurrences.

As part of the BASI's process of selective investigation, all occurrences are classified into one of five categories. Each category indicates the level of effort which is put into the investigation and

ANSWER.PARA: thereby inadvertently indicates the seriousness of each occurrence. For example, a Category 1 occurrence would be an accident involving a major passenger aircraft killing all onboard (this type of occurrence would be a full International Civil Aviation Organisation team investigation given the highest priority). An accident involving a regional airline with multiple fatalities would be a Category 2 investigation. A Category 5 occurrence is one that has such little safety value that all BASI does is register the fact that it was reported.

PARA.TAB: On this basis BASI would consider Category 1, 2 and 3 occurrences as being serious and Category 4 and 5 occurrences as being not very serious. The figures below indicate Category 1 to 4 accidents and 1 to 3 incidents from November 1990 to November 1993.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Transport has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

(b) Both pilots held an endorsement for the Navajo aircraft.

(2) The Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has provided the following advice. By way of background, Civil Aviation Orders (CAO) 82.3 and 20.18, respectively, require a Regular Public Transport (RPT) flight to be conducted under Instrument Flight Rules (IFR), and an aeroplane operated under IFR to be equipped with an automatic pilot.

CAO 20.18 allows an RPT (below 5700kg) aeroplane, not equipped with an automatic pilot, to be operated under IFR, if there are two control seats and the one control seat is occupied by the pilot in command, and the other control seat is occupied by a commercial or air transport pilot licence holder.

The Minimum Equipment List (MEL) for the Monarch Airlines Piper Navajo (VH-NDU) aircraft allowed the automatic pilot to be inoperative for IFR flight, provided two instrument rated pilots, endorsed on the aircraft, were on board the aircraft.
(Civil Aviation Regulation 2(1) defines "co-pilot" as a pilot serving in any piloting capacity, other than the pilot in command.)
The VH-NDU RPT operation was a single pilot operation.

In respect of the pilot (not being the pilot-in-command) occupying the other control seat on VH-NDU on 11 June 1993, this pilot was not serving in any "piloting capacity", but was acting as a replacement for the automatic pilot in accordance with the MEL.
In relation to the second pilot required by the MEL on VH-NDU, there were no specified duties and no hours requirements.
The qualifications required for both pilots operating VH-NDU were a Commercial Pilot licence, an instrument rating, and an endorsement on the aircraft.
The co-pilot who occupied the other control seat of VH-NDU on 11 June 1993 had satisfied that requirement.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 3 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Does the Australian (Surveying) and Land Information Group (AUSLIG) intend to establish a Global Positioning Base Station in Hobart, with the Tasmanian Department of Environment and Planning acting as their agent, in direct competition with at least two other base station operations.

(2) Has AUSLIG undertaken a market survey to establish the size of the potential market; if so, what does the survey indicate about the extent to which the establishment of a new facility in Tasmania will: (a) duplicate other established services; (b) compete with these services; (c) impact on the operations of the companies established; if not, will these issues be assessed prior to the establishment of the facility.
(3) Has AUSLIG considered contracting out services to local Base Stations; if not, why not.
(4) Does AUSLIG share the same costs as private industry such as indirect taxes, building costs, rental, depreciation, etcetera.

(5) What are the proposed AUSLIG charges for their services and will the charges undercut the established operators and reflect true commercial costs, or will AUSLIG merely be ensuring some return on under-utilised equipment.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have been advised that the answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1) AUSLIG is establishing a GPS base station in Hobart as part of a national network of Global Positioning System (GPS) stations. This network serves two primary functions—geodetic and integrity monitoring and will be used by Commonwealth agencies such as the Civil Aviation Authority, Defence and the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. These primary functions are part of AUSLIG's national and international public interest activities. They provide significant benefits to the Australian community including more efficient and accurate surveying and mapping, and information for crustal motion and greenhouse monitoring. As a secondary function, AUSLIG can provide positioning data for GPS users. The AUSLIG station will provide a more accurate service and a broader capability to state government, local government and industry users in Tasmania than is available from other base station operations.

(2) Because the geodetic and integrity monitoring services are being undertaken as part of AUSLIG's public interest obligations, there was no need for a market survey with regard to these services and none was undertaken. While a market survey for the positioning services has not been conducted yet, AUSLIG generally prefers to operate with private sector partners for the provision of such services. Accordingly, AUSLIG and the Tasmanian Department of Environment Land and Planning have held preliminary discussions with a private base station operator in northern Tasmania with a view to establishing an agreement for joint distribution of GPS positioning information.

(3) Existing local base stations could not support AUSLIG's geodetic and integrity monitoring requirements. Local base stations operate on single frequency whereas dual frequency operation is essential for the level of accuracy required for those functions. The location of existing base stations and the inability to allow dedicated access to equipment were other reasons for their unsuitability. As mentioned above, AUSLIG would prefer to work with other base station operators for the provision of positioning data.
(4) AUSLIG's commercial operations are subject to the same costs as private industry when servicing the private sector.

(5) Market rates will apply to the positioning data that AUSLIG makes available for sale to GPS users and, as such, will be competitive with rates charged by other base station operators. The geodetic and integrity monitoring services are being undertaken by AUSLIG as part of its public interest obligations at nominal charges. These services are not being provided by private base station operators.

(2) How many full-fee paying students were registered as attending ELICOS institutions at 30 June each year since 1986, by State.

(3) As at 30 June each year since 1986, what was the number of students registered with ELICOS institutions who had: (a) up to 1 year; (b) between 1 and 2 years; (c) between 2 and 3 years; and (d) more than 3 years, residential permit remaining.

PARA.TAB: (1) No statistics are kept within the Department on the total number of full-fee students attending ELICOS institutions during a financial year but this data is collected as at 30 June each year.

PARA.TAB: (3) The Department of Employment, Education and Training does not collect this data. The Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs advises that, prior to February 1991, visas/entry permits for all students were issued for the duration of the course, to a maximum period of twelve months, plus one month. TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Social Security, upon notice, on 24 February 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Why did the department choose the Taiwanese company ACER Computer Australia to supply over $30 million worth of personal computers (PCs).
(2) Is it a fact that:
(a) the ACER PCs are likely to become obsolete more quickly than those provided by some of the rival tenderers;
(b) ACER tendered for the contract 6 months before it signed the Government's Fixed Term Arrangement; and
(c) the other short listed tenderers have been asked to be part of a panel of possible suppliers to the project.
(3) Have the companies on the panel of possible suppliers been provided with details of the purpose of this panel and their role on the panel.
(4) How does the decision to choose ACER fit in with Government policies to buy Australian made and owned products where this is possible.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Social Security has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

PARA.TAB: (1) ACER was recommended by the Department of Social Security's (DSS) systems integrator for the Network Replacement Project, BHP IT, as providing the best value for money to the Commonwealth. DSS agreed with that recommendation.

(b) The Department issued a request for tender for a systems integrator and solution in 1992. Due to rapid developments in the PC assembly industry, including prices and design, BHP IT issued a request for quotation for PCs in September 1993 which closed in November 1993. ACER had signed a fixed term agreement in April 1993, well before the purchasing decision was made.
(c) Three other short listed companies have been advised that they will be asked to be part of a panel of possible PC suppliers to DSS.
(3) The companies have not yet been fully briefed on the detailed operation of the panel. They are aware in broad terms of the purpose of the panel. Formal briefing should take place in early March.

(4) The decision is consistent with government policy for Information Technology purchases. ACER is required to be treated as an Australian supplier of IT equipment based on its Fixed Term Agreement with the Commonwealth under the Partnerships program.
